conclusion: All four shadows are cast by the same elevated light source.
When the light source is moved directly backward (away from the objects but at the same height), the rays striking the objects become more oblique with respect to the table surface.
Oblique lighting makes every shadow (A, B, C, D) stretch away from its parent object and become longer.
Because the light still moves along the same line, the directions of the shadows on the table do not change significantly—what mainly changes is their length.
The farther an object is from the light as compared with its height above the table, the larger (longer) its shadow becomes.
All objects experience this proportionally, so their relative shadow sizes stay roughly the same.

When the light source is moved backward above the objects, shadows A, B, C, and D will all slide slightly forward on the slab (i.e., in the direction opposite the light’s motion) and will each become noticeably longer/larger while keeping approximately the same orientations and relative sizes to one another.
